In the pilot book of the Australian coast, which is the master mariner's guide, it is stated that this portion of the coast is the most indented of -any of our littoral. Along that coast, with the exception perhaps of the Bay of Fundy, the highest tides in the world prevail, and ordinary spring tides of . 2.8 feet rush . along the coast and create & current, in places, equal to 10 knots an hour. Some of the steamers trading along that portion of the coast do not average 10 knots, and it will therefore be seen that if vessels are in the vicinity of the coast their danger is very great owing to the presence of numerous islands. The number of shipwrecks has not been large because the trade on that portion of the coast is comparatively small, and the skilled master mariners in charge of the vessels exercise great caution. I have been in conversation with some of these men, who have made certain recommendations as to where lighthouses should be placed, which I shall now submit to the Minister. The lighthouses on the whole of the Western Australian coast number only nineteen, whilst the number on other parts of the Australiancoastis over 100. As the Western Australian coast is equal to one-third of our whole coast line, it will be seen that the lighting; is altogether inadequate.. It. may be.- said that, because vessels, pass, along, that coast, only occasionally,, lighthouses are not required,, but tha need. i& all the greater, because on the well-lighted' portions of the coast the course is well known.

talk.start.para: - Are. there, only- nineteen lights apart, from the leading lights, into the. harbors?

- Yes-. There are- only two, ships a month- to- Port- Darwin, but the Government have provided ten lights between Cape Don and Port Darwin, which is a very short distance, while on the ether stretch- of 625* miles- which I have mentioned there is not one. There should' be a- light on La Crosse Island,, at the: entrance- to the Wyndham- Harbor. We* are- told- Chat it was on Ea Crosse Island that De Rougement re.de-. turtles 0.fi course,, there, are turtles. there.. De Rougement's veracity was. disbelieved when-,, he having mentioned" that on. his trip across the Northern Territory he did not, see anything ; but. an Australian who happened- to be in the, audience, asked,

speech.para: Did you not notice the overland tele,graph line?"' At that. De Rougement collapsed. A light, is necessary at. La Crosse. Island, where- there is considerable shipping at this time, of the year,, and vessel's,, including those, of the; Common wealth Government Line, are. in danger if they arrive at night, as there is a. 10-knot current. Master mariners, have said that, even when their vessels are anchored, the swirl of the. tide is alarming, and the greatest precaution has to be taken to prevent dragging. If a light; were stationed at that point, they would be able to know their bearings. I do not profess to possess any nautical knowledge, but I have travelled up and' down the. coast, occasionally for- many- years. There is a. 2'1-ft. rise and fall at the. mouth of Cambridge Gulf, upon- which- Wyndham is- situated. A lighthouse should also be built, at Troughton Island, another at Low Rock - probably a gas buoy would1 do- there - and one at Corneille Island. Thais would enable boats1 to- go. through the Peneton Pass, Trough ton Pass, and- make- it unnecessary for vessel's going from Wyndham to Derby to go out past the Solothurn Bank, thus saving- 27 miles-. Ships, working up the; north-west coast have to. proceed with great caution at night owing to, the. strong currents'.. The* next suggested sites: are on. each side of what. is. known as. the Meda Pass, going Sato- Derby,,, one each on. The: Twins Island and. Hunter Island: There is a high- tide audi a. 10-knot rip through the Meda- and' Escape Passes-, through, which. I have been when there has been a, wall of water 5 or 6 feet, high. At present, boats-, coming ta Derby at night must anchor outside King Sound!, but if? there: were, lights- at the islands; I have mentioned:,, they could proceed- to port, instead-, of losing probably/ twelve hours, waiting foc day/light, which involves a cost of £59:.

The tides at Ring's- Sound, are- as bad as- at any place Known to man-. There, is a portion of King's Sound which has l'ong been known as' the " grave-yard." The divers, for pearl shell - like, all men. who work for the- recovery of precious- gems*frequently take, great, risks, and, numbers of them have lost their lives by having had their air-line cut, A number* of deaths have occurred in the. last few years. A light is required at the East Lacepedl Group, on the- route, to Broome-. If a light, were established- there it. would' enable ships- to take the inside channel at night, ana? save thirty-six- miles- of the journey, by enabling them to. make. Derby without casting- anchor outside King's Sound-. A light should' be- placed at Legendre Island:,, off Port. Sampson,, to show the way to the very important port of Roeburne At- present, no light is; to be> seen until slips- get right round the point of the island. Several' ships have been wrecked on that coast.. It. would- be impossible fca* an outsider to> get, along- the north-west coast, successfully-, even with charts'. Only a master mariner, who knows: the. coast, can travel; in- safety. The cost of installing these- lights- would not be, very great. I understand that the Governor Musgrave, which attends the lighthouses once in six months, will not attempt this, coast at certain periods. The. Government, could, install lights- that would not need attendants. The Governor Musgrave' makes periodical visits to the- automatic, lights already established1, and Keeps- them- in order. The lights installed in what is known, as; Mary Ann-. Passage- are ineffective. The light on the north side is» at Sandy Island, and on the south side at Airlie. Island, but a mile of the, channel half way between the lights is obscured- as the lights are out or range. A gas buoy should be placed at Sandy Bay, near Large Island. It would be visible for 10 miles, and it would cost very little. No white man cares to go to certain parts of the coast in this locality, between Derby and Wyndham. The country is in the possession of well-fed and fierce Australian blacks. At different times fifty or sixty men have landed on the rocks from pearling luggers which have been wrecked. They were daring men, but few of them have been heard of after the landing. The writer of the pilot book gives some particulars about the natives in these districts. On page 154 of the book, referring to the natives near Cape Londonderry, he says -

quote.para: The reports of the treacherous character of the natives should be borne in mind.

speech.para: Of Napier Broome Bay, he says-;-

quote.para: The natives on the shores of Napier Broome Bay, and also on Eclipse and adjacent islands, were hostile at the time of survey.

speech.para: That was in 1884. No missionaries have been near since then to teach them the white man's idea of civilization. With respect to Bougaineville Island the book states : -

quote.para: The country is inhabited by a suspicious race of aborigines, who appear to h&.ve no contact with white people. It has been unsafe to land singly or without firearms.

speech.para: Bigge Island, west of Montague Sound, is mentioned and the inhabitants described as follows: -

quote.para: The natives are a savage race, of good physique, armed with spears, clubs, and boomerangs, and remarkably agile. They appear to be unaccustomed to white people. Landing was resisted. No attempt should be made to hold intercourse with them in small parties, or without firearms.

speech.para: Of the natives in the Maret group, it is stated -

quote.para: Maret group is frequented by natives, and caution is necessary when landing.

speech.para: These interesting remarks are made on Camden Harbor -

quote.para: From a high hill on the southern shore of Camden Island most luxuriant and well-watered country was seen over the low southern shore, extending in an east-south-easterly direction towards the Glenelg River. Part of this rich land approaches within five miles of Camden Harbor. In the vicinity of Camden Island, the natives were hostile. A settlement, formed on its shores, was abandoned long ago for this reason.

speech.para: Honorable members have heard something of Yampi Sound, in the Buccaneer Archipelago, because of the famous iron deposits there. Several pearlers who have gone out from Derby towards Yampi Sound have been wrecked, and on landing in the sound have been murdered by the natives. Sufficient has been said to show how necessary it is that these lights should be installed. This portion of the coast should be treated in the same way as other portions of our coast are treated, . and we should do what we can for the hinterland country. If the Minister for Works examines the chart I have on the table he will find that in the East Indies the Dutch people have all their channels and water-ways lighted like Bourke-street, although many of the places have only a ship a month.

talk.start.para: . - I shall only be able to reply briefly to the points raised, because the time at my disposal' is limited. The honorable member for Grey has moved that this vote be reduced by £1, because he says no provision is made for improving the housing accommodation along the East-West line. I inform him that an amount of £23,662 is provided -on the Loan Estimates for the construction of residential accommodation along the East- West line. I inspected Rawlinna with the honorable member, and know exactly what the position is. It is said that the houses erected there are not worth the money. All honorable members know that it is impossible, under existing conditions, to build, a very good type of house for £400, whether it be at a spot half-way along the East-West railway line or in the capital cities. What struck me about the accommodation was that there was no privacy. I have instructed the Railway Commissioner to erect a, paling fence round each cottage. That will cost a fair amount of money, but no extra rent will be charged for the added' convenience. I do not deny that the accommodation at some of the stations on the East- West line is poor and of a. temporary character. That is largely because many of the stopping places are not yet permanently determined. Water is one of the main' factors in this matter. Rawlinna is a permanent station, and for that reason the accommodation there is better than in some other places. As soon as we establish permanent stopping places a better class of accommodation will be provided. With respect to the Kyogle-Brisbane railway, I can assure honorable members that the Commonwealth Government is anxious to cooperate with the State in constructing the line. Negotiations are going on at present. A very fine speech was made by the honorable member for Kalgoorlie in explanation of the need for lights on our north-west coast. As an ex-sailor I appreciated very much what he said. Lighthouses are under the control of the Department of Trade and Customs. An amount of £140,000 has been provided this year for two new vessels for tending lighthouses. One of these will work on the Western Australian coast. I was glad to hear the reference to automatic lights. Already £250,000 has been spent in providing these lights, and. a saving of £11,000 a year has been made by removing the old type of light and replacing it with the new automatic light. I suggest that the honorable member state his case to the Department of Trade and Customs, which, I am sure, will give it the fullest consideration.
.- In view of the assurance that the Minister for Works and Railways has given, I desire to withdraw my amendment.

speech.para: Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

talk.start.para: - The time at which the vote on this Department must be taken has arrived.

speech.para: Proposed vote (Works, and Railways £834,849) agreed to.
Postmaster-General's Department.
Proposed Vote, £7,997,131.

talk.start.para: . - I intended to say something on the Budget in regard to the Post Office Department generally, but I am confined now to the matters dealt with in the Estimates before the Committee. I shall not take up much time, as I know that honorable members desire to speak about post-office' and telephone construction. I am very glad that the criticism levelled against the Department I have the honour to administer has been very friendly. With regard to telephones, honorable members know that last year we spent something like £2,000,000 on constructional work. I want to pay a tribute to Mr. Poynton, who held the office of Postmaster-General prior to my taking over the administration of the Department. He set out to catch up with some of the arrears of construction, and he went so far as to widen ' the concessions to country districts generally. The present Government propose to further extend the facilities for communication in the country districts. Honorable members will recognise that this is a work of very great magnitude when they remember that we are spending this year some £4,000,000. If we had before us a proposal for the construction of a railway at a cost of £4,000,000 we would hardly expect to spend the money in one year. It is, however, proposed to spend the £4,000,000 on the Post and Telegraph Department's operations during the coming year. That is almost double the amount expended last year. I hope honorable members . will recognise that this is a very big work, and will give a great deal of employment. The expenditure will cover only works that are absolutely necessary, and that represent only a part of the expenditure of £10,000,000, which will be completed in a future programme of construction for 1924-25. The public seem to think that . it is quite an easy matter to make connexions with the telephone service, but when it is explained that it costs as much per mile to lay down conduits and cables in the capital cities as to lay down a line of railway, it will be seen that it is not an easy matter to make some of the connexions for which people are clamouring to-day. The arrears are very great. Something like 14,000 people are still waiting for connexion with the telephone service. Since the present Government came into office we have connected some 3,000 per month, which, I think, is a very great feat. It exceeds anything done by the Post and Telegraph Department before, and is an absolute record. I feel sure that we will shortly be making 4,000 telephone connexions per month, and we must do so if we are to give in a reason- able time the service which people are looking for. Some honorable members opposite have said that most of the money is being expended in city areas, and others have said that most of it is being spent in country areas, so the Department would appear to have struck the happy medium. I propose to explain what is being done in both city and country areas. The references made by the honorable members for Hume (Mr. Parker Moloney), Angas (Mr. Gabb), and, I think, Kalgoorlie (Mr. A. Green) were particularly to the expenditure on buildings, and not so much to the amount of £2,980,000 which appeared in the Loan Estimates for telephones and telegraph works. What we are proposing to spend is £3,200,000 on telephones and telegraphs; £729,366 on buildings, and £82,400 on sites. In 1922-23 we spent £2,000,000 on telephone and telegraph works, and £182,818 on buildings. The allocation of the £3,200,000 proposed to be expended this year is as follows: - New South Wales £645,300 in metropolitan areas, and £701,200 in country areas, or a total of £1,346,500. In Victoria, £444,400 in metropolitan areas, and £326,900 in, country areas, or a total of £771*300. In Queensland, £159,500 in metropolitan areas, and 322,600 in country areas, total £482,100. In South Australia, £185,700 in metropolitan areas and £202,500 in country areas, total £338,200. In Western Australia, £56,100 in metropolitan areas and £132,600 in country areas, total £188,700. In Tasmania, £31,000 in metropolitan areas and £42,200 in country areas, total £73,200. These figures give a grand total of £1,472,000 for metropolitan areas, and £1,728,000 for country areas; 46 per cent, of the total expenditure will be in the metropolitan areas, and 54 per cent, in the country districts. I should say that this does not represent the whole of the money being expended in country districts for the reason that it is necessary to dismantle a good deal of work in city areas, and many switch boards, conduits and cables are transferred from city to country areas. The country districts get the benefit of this dismantled material with little cost to them. Taking that into consideration the actual amount which is to be expended in the country districts will be much more than the figures I have just given.
- Is the capital value of the dismantled material still debited to city works?'

- Yes, mostly. The material is simply removed to country districts. Honorable members will understand that the capacity of conduits and cables in the capital cities is in some cases soon outgrown by the. increased traffic and the dismantled' material is quite useful for the country districts. With regard to cable material there has been a great deal of difficulty in the past in getting this material. In city areas, very many applications for telephones have been outstanding for a very long time. It is a very difficult matter indeed because of the lack of cables to make the connexions required. I have explained that the cost of laying down conduits and cables of 1,000 pairs of wires amounts to over £5,000 per mile, and many would-be subscribers must remain without connexions until such time as conduits are laid down, and the cable arrives from overseas. When we are in a position to do so, we shall, instead of connecting one subscriber, connect hundreds, or even a thousand, by a single cable. I must confess that the telephone system in the capital cities is very bad indeed, and the position in Sydney is probably worse than in any of the other capital cities of Australia. There the junction lines between the exchanges are not sufficient for the number of persons who want connexions between them. There" are only fifty junction lines for 500 people,- and if more than fifty wish to be connected at one time, the whole automatic exchange is thrown out of order. As a result we are to-day really spoiling the valuable machinery contained in the exchanges. We are making an effort to have additional junction lines placed in position at the earliest date. We are trying to give the community as soon as possible the service which should be given in the capital cities ' as well as in the country districts. Honorable members in discussing the Budget compared the amount of money spent in the capital cities with the expenditure in the country districts.

speech.para: The following statement shows the ap- changes to be erected in the capital cities proximate cost of the principal large ex- of the different States : -

This vast expenditure represents a fifteen years' programme, and will not recur, for we naturally expect that the provision we are making now will give at least ten or twelve years' service. The conditions in Melbourne are very similar to those in Sydney. There are thousands of applicants for telephone services, and X believe that if the Department were prepared to announce to the people of those two cities to-morrow that they could all get telephone communication, it would be snowed under with applications. As soon as the exchanges are built the bulk of the work will have been done, and the further expenditure will be only in the laying of cables and wires to connect many thousands of people to the exchanges.

Upon country telephone trunk lines we are spending in New South Wales £426,000, independent of ' the expenditure upon subscribers' lines. The condition of affairs to-day is such that the subscriber often has to wait for an hour or two to get telephone connexion with country districts. The traffic that is offering over these trunk lines is immense. The proposed expenditure of £426,000 represents only the present year's programme, and is for urgent works. I appeal to honorable members who are particularly anxious to get trunk lines and subscribers' lines in their own districts to have a little patience,, because we shall experience difficulty in spending £4,000,000 on constructional work m one year. On Victorian trunk lines we are proposing to spend £199,989. In this State the conditions are much the same as in New South Wales. Tn some cases we are duplicating and triplicating the present trunk line between the capital cities and outside districts. We are also cutting out of the trunk lines many country towns. Where small towns are in close proximity to bigger towns we are putting in a direct line, so that the small' town may have communication with the bigger town- with which it does most of its business, without holding up traffic on the main trunk. On Queensland country trunk lines the expenditure will be £263,719, and I hope that will satisfy the Queensland representatives. Where the distances are so great as they are in Queensland, it is essential to give the people conveniences even if they cost a little more. A telephone is even more necessary in outback districts than in the capital cities, and I may be forgiven if my sympathies lean a little towards the country rather than the city'. However, I do not wish to raise the cry of country versus city, because I realize that one cannot live without the other. I propose to give to the city the conditions essential to an up-to-date service, and to ' the country the sympathetic treatment it deserves. The expenditure in South Australia upon telephone trunk lines will be £105,579; in .Western Australia, £105,790; and in Tasmania, £26,252. I ask honorable members to. think of what these trunk lines mean. In New South Wales 128 lines will total 7,415 miles; Victoria, 101 lines, 5,179'miles; Queensland, 107 lines, 7,096 miles; South Australia, 74 lines, 3,481 miles'; Western Australia, 25 lines, 1,688 miles; Tasmania, 19 lines, 778 miles; or a- total mileage of 25,637 double miles, equal to 51,274 miles of single wire.
Tha following is a list of the telephone trunk lines to be erected: -

The number of telephones connected on 30th June, 1922, was 258,477, and, on the 30th June, 1923, approximately 287,000, showing an increase of 28,523. In the five months since the present Government took office, an average of 3,000 subscribers per month has been connected, and half of those are in country districts. As a matter of fact, applications are being received at the rate of about 4,000 per month, so we have a good deal of leeway to make up before we can satisfy everybody

talk.start.para: - How long will it be before all the applicants in big cities like Melbourne are connected?

- We hope that most of them will be connected in twelve months. We are laying down many conduits and cables with 1,000 pair wires in each, so that thousands of subscribers can be readily connected in a week or a fortnight after the exchanges are ready. In the past we have had a great difficulty in getting a supply of switchboards and cables, but at the present time orders are coming forward very well. The whole of the cable has been coming from England, but the Department has given a contract to an Australian firm to manufacture cable in the coming year. The whole of the orders for copper wire, totalling 50,000 or 60,000 miles, have been placed with an Australian firm. As indicating the progress that is being made and the revenue that is flowing into the telephone service, I may inform the Committee that the revenue from calls in July, 1922, was £278,794, and in July, 1923, £302,283, representing an increase of £23,489. Similar figures could be quoted for every other month, and I 'feel sure that, if the Department were able to give prompter connexion on the telephones, the business would be increased very largely. The new work to be put in hand will mean the employment of very many temporary hands. At the present time, 2.655 returned soldiers are employed on telephone and telegraph works, and we propose to engage another 700 to help in carrying out the 1923-24 programme.

speech.para: Some of the concessions made to the public in regard to telephone services were stated in the Budget speech. In future, we propose to base trunk-line charges on direct mileage instead of route mileage. Very many country districts have lines running parallel, .within 10 or 1.5 miles, but the route mileage travelled by the telephone message may be 60 miles. By adopting the direct mileage instead of the route mileage, we are placing country districts on exactly the same footing as the cities. Every country district subscriber will be able, without paying a trunk-line fee, to communicate within a 5-mile radius of the exchange to which he is connected. Country subscribers will thus be in the same position as if they were connected with a city exchange. The rental for the use of Government poles has been reduced from 10s. per mile to 5s. per mile for metallic circuit, or 2s. 6d. per mile per wire, and for lines constructed wholly by the Department from £2 to 30s. per mile; Formerly subscribers in country districts were asked to pay two years' rental in advance, while the city subscriber was asked for only one year's rental. I have directed that the city and country subscribers shall be placed on the same basis. If it is safe to accept one year's rental from a city subscriber, it should be equally safe to accept it from a man in the country. In the city, up to £65 per subscriber can be expended in providing a subscriber's line, but only £21 could be expended in the country. Henceforth, up to £65 may be spent on a country subscriber's line. A further disability imposed on the country subscriber was that, even though there, were two or three applicants in a certain district, the Department would not erect a line for more than 2 miles from the exchange. In future, if four or five people in' a district make application to become subscribers, the limitation of £65 per subscriber will apply instead of the distance limitation.

talk.start.para: - Does not the country man have to give a seven-years' guarantee? I do not think that prevails in the cities.
- The guarantee is over and above the £65 per subscriber.
- Does the Minister mean that if five subscribers to a country exchange make application, the line may be extended a distance of 10 miles?

- No. The proposal is to spend £65 per subscriber, and in this respect the country subscriber will be placed oh exactly the same footing as the subscriber in city areas. The honorable member for Bass (Mr. Jackson) referred just now to the length of the poles. The Act does not permit wires being less than 12 feet in height being erected along fences, and less than 18 feet over roads. I intend to introduce an amendment of the Act to enable us to place wires on poles 8 feet high, instead of 12 feet along certain routes. It is not proposed to use these shorter poles in cities or towns, or in places where there are a number of wires, but in the more sparsely populated districts in Western Australia, Queensland, and the Northern Territory. In some areas it is absolutely essential that we should erect iron poles. I had an estimate for a line from Camooweal to the present overland telegraph line. The cartage of the posts for the line would have cost £20,000., I propose to cut that cost in half by reducing the height of the pole's-.

.In the Postmaster-General's Department there is an item £30,000 for the conveyance of mails between the mainland and Tasmania by certain steamship companies, under contracts with the Department. I should like the Minister to give some information as to when these contracts will expire. ' If they have only a short term to run, I suggest the advisability of not renewing them for a lengthy period, because this expenditure of £30,000 would .be an important factor in the profitable working of the Common-, wealth Line of steamers between the mainland and Tasmania. I know that I would not be in order if I referred at length to the necessity for the Commonwealth employing Government steamers in this trade, but, unfortunately, owing to the declaration of urgency in respect of the Estimates, I was deprived of my opportunity to refer to this matter when the Department which controls shipping was under discussion. Once again I enter my protest against this method of doing business. The action of the Government is preventing fair and reasonable debate on the Estimates. Recently we passed a Bill which contains a provision for the appointment of a Board to take over and control the Commonwealth Line. The Board will have authority to purchase suitable vessels, and if it considered that course desirable, to put Commonwealth vessels on the run between the mainland and Tasmania, in competition with privately-owned ships. This sum of £30,000 now being paid under contract to the various . shipping companies for' the conveyance of mails to and from Tasmania, will be a very important factor in the successful running of any Commonwealth steamers that may be put into commission in that trade. Unfortunately, owing to the tactics of the Government, I have been deprived of the chance to have a vote recorded in connexion with a . motion for :the appointment of a commission to inquire into and- report upon the advisability of Commonwealth steamers engaging in the trade between the mainland and Hobart. I hope, however, that we may yet have an opportunity of getting a vote, because I am satisfied that a majority of the members were sympathetically interested in the motion. The Commission could do its work within a week, and submit a report to Parliament. I believe that the Board to be appointed to control Commonwealth shipping will give early attention to this question, and I am satisfied that it will not be long beforeCommonwealth vessels are put on the run between the mainland and Tasmania. In that event, the amount paid under the mail contract with privately-owned vessels could be paid as a subsidy to the Commonwealth ships, and be an important factor in their success.
.- MrCook
- I call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.']

- Ever since I have been a member of the House complaints have been raised during the discussion on the Estimates about the insufficiency of the time allowed to debate the .items of proposed expenditure; but even if the time were extended four- fold, I believe that similar complaints would be made. I wish to compliment the Postmaster-General (Mr. Gibson) and the competent staff under his control for the services they are rendering. I have had a good deal to do with the Post and Telegraph Department, which is a governmental activity which comes into, closer touch with the general community than any other. During the time I have been a. member of this House, I have always received the greatest courtesy from postal officials, even down to the messenger boys, and I think it is only right to pay them some small tribute for the efficient service they render. The position held by the Minister has always been regarded as a political grave, but I am satisfied that if the present Postmaster-General continues his good work it will be a long time before it can again be so regarded. A good deal has been. said concerning the necessity for providing country districts with the facilities enjoyed by the people in the metropolitan areas, and it is gratifying that the Government have submitted a policy which will materially tend to increase development in the outback country. The Minister will be justified in making inquiries into the manner in which city telephone cabinets are working, in an endeavour to ascertain why they constantly get out of order. The honorable member for Bass (|Mr. Jackson) mentioned this matter a few days ago, and I have lately had a similar experience. The telephones, at railway stations particularly, are frequently out of order, and consequently a good deal of revenue is lost. There is also an insufficient number of telephone cabinets in the metropolitan areas, and revenue is lost for this cause, because people cannot waste time in waiting an opportunity to call subscribers. I was interested to hear the Minister's statement that it is proposed to manufacture cable in Australia. If this work is undertaken, employment will be provided for a large number of our own people. I trust that some of the cable coming forward will be ear-marked for Geelong, where there have been numerous complaints owing to persons being unable to get connected with the exchange. The installation of an additional switchboard at. the Geelong, Post Office is also a pressing need. The existing boards are full, and even if a permanent board is not available, perhaps the Minister will authorize the installation of a temporary board to accommodate 100 subscribers to overcome the present difficulty. Improvement should be made in the accommodation provided for the Geelong telephone attendants. The constant clicking of the apparatus must be very irritating to operators. I also understand that the temperature of the room in which they work has to be regulated, and that moist air, which would interfere with the delicate mechanism, must not be admitted. It is intended, I believe, to provide additional facilities for the telephone attendants in a room adjoining that which they now occupy, and I trust that provision will be made in this direction at an early date. The traffic on the trunk line between Geelong and Ballarat is frequently congested, and at times there is difficulty in establishing communication between the two places. The difficulty could be overcome by the construction of a line 8 miles in length from Fyansford to Murgheboluc, and I am glad to learn that this work which is now contemplated may soon be authorized. As the revenue of the Department has been buoyant, those, in charge of allowance post-offices might well be granted an additional allowance, as the amounts received in some cases are too small. I am sorry that a "Werribee mail delivery service on the northern side of the railway line has not been arranged, and that the Department has not complied with the request of the Albion Ratepayers Association to place a letter-box on the Albion railway station. Naturally, all the work requiring attention in my electorate has not been done, but it is pleasing to know that attention has been given to many of the requests I have submitted.

. - I wish to refer briefly to the development of the wireless broad-casting system, which is a matter that should be given careful consideration by honorable members on account of its importance to our country districts. An agitation has been going on for some time for the provision of wireless broadcasting facilities. A deputation met the Postmaster-General recently, and in consequence a number of regulations have been framed which are on the . table of the House at present. Unless objection is taken to them by 15th August, they will become law and will have all the force of 'an Act of Parliament. I have 'nothing to say agains.t the action of the Postmaster-General in endeavouring to establish this system.' If it is successful it will be a great boon to people who live in the more remote parts of the country. It will increase the pleasure of life to them, and will enable them to obtain information of important matters which occur in the capital cities or in other parts of Australia. But I have received several letters which seem to indicate that the regulations are not altogether satisfactory.
- Can the honorable member tell me from whom he received the letters ?

- One came from the Wireless Development- Association of Victoria, 323 Flinders-street, Melbourne ;. another from Mr. John Payne, editor of the Australasian Wireless Review, 143 Avoca-street, Randwick, Sydney; and another from Mr. C. W. Norris, 346 Post Office-place, Melbourne. In the opinion of the writers the regulations are framed differently from those which operate in New Zealand, Great Britain, and America. They have requested me to take action to prevent the regulations from becoming law. I told them that I could not do that, as the time for which Parliament would be sitting would not permit it. But I promised that I would take the first opportunity to bring the matter under the notice of the Postmaster-General. I understand that the Minister framed these regulations after a conference was held, and I suppose, therefore, that he has some justification for them. We should make these facilities available as far as possible to all the people in the out-back settlements, and not only to the wealthier classes. If we can use this means to bring a little sunshine into the lives of the folk out-back we should do it. Our people should not be in a position any less advantageous than that of the people of Great Britain or other parts of the British Dominions. The letter from the Wireless Development Association of Victoria reads - 323 Flinders-street, Melbourne. 9th August, 1923.

speech.para: Dear Sir,

We received your letter this morning, and have much pleasure in forwarding another copy of the cuttings. We believe that to-day is the last day, on which a protest can be lodged in the House on the Wireless Bill this session.

While the Postmaster-General states that there was no opposition at the time of the conference, we would like to point out that at the conference the public was not represented, and it is the public's interest that we wish to protect. The only interests that have been protected by the present regulations are any broadcasting station which might start, and there is no limit in the fees that they may demand from the public for their service. In the event of more than one broadcasting station starting and charging for services, the public will have to pay for both broadcasting stations if they desire to listen to both, and so the ordinary working man will be debarred Prom listening in. This is not so in New Zealand, America, England, South America, and Europe, and' why should Australia be placed in this position ? You will also notice that broadcasting stations have the monopoly for five pears, which means that we are held up by them for five years.
If the regulations are amended, they undoubtedly will claim compensation against the Government.
We would be pleased to give you any other help in this matter.
Yours faithfully,

item.label: C.
item.para: W. Chum, Treasurer.

speech.para: According to that letter certain companies are to be given a monopoly for five years.
Mr. Gibson.That is not so.

talk.start.para: - I am pleased to hear that. The writer of that letter points out that if such a monopoly were given, and subsequently it was found necessary to alter the agreement in the public interests, the companies which had been granted a monopoly would claim compensation. This association forwarded a copy of a letter from C. W. Norris, of Norris & Skelly, 346 Post Office-place, Melbourne, July 1923. It reads: -

quote.para: " BROADCASTING OR THE SEALED BOX? "
To the Editor, Electrical Times.

Now that the recent Conference called by the Minister (Mr. Gibson, P.M.G.) is over and the discussion has been published, the majority (which have just discovered that there has been a conference affecting their business as electrical traders) on hearing the result stand aghast !

While we all agree that broadcasting must be governed, and, possibly, subsidized - in small populated areas such as Australia - what we cannot understand is that the Australian Government has agreed to demand that, before the public can even purchase a receiving set, they must pay a fee to one broadcasting station - that is, after paying 10s. for a licence then they are allowed to purchase a sealed box. If they do not like the particular station for which they have already paid their money, then back they go with their sealed box to their dealer and pay a small fee to have same altered to another wave length; then it will be necessary to pay a fee to this broadcasting station, and they are allowed to take home their sealed box again, and so on and so on.

Do you honestly think the public will do this ? Mr. Gibson stated to myself and others, while on a deputation of protest, that it will be just like a book-lending library - if you don't like one you just go to another.
Yes, but remember that you pay and you can choose at random what book you want, but not so with the sealed box.

I would suggest that, as the Government is so good as to sponsor the broadcasting companies which will have every possibility of becoming monopolies, as in England, that they do the job properly here, as suggested below : -

item.para: Raise the licence fee to £3 3s. per annum.
Genuine experimenters be protected as at present, and charged 10s. per annum.

Appoint a Board, consisting of representatives of the Radio Department, broadcasting companies, traders, press and others directly interested in broadcasting (these to be paid a small fee, if any at all), to controlbroadcasting.

Moneys received in fees to be allotted as follows : - Five shillings of each to go to the Radio Department for the control and supervision of wireless, which will include strict supervision by their officers (heavy penalties for breaches), the balance to be paid into a fund to subsidize broadcasting.
The Board to accept programmes, which will include entertainments, public notices, weather reports, &c, also times for services.

quote.para: Then call tenders for thU service, successful tenders to be under bond to maintain the programmes.

item.para: One subsidized broadcasting station to be allotted to each capital city. More as funds from fees permit for other centres.

That the licences be issued to companies or firms desirous of broadcasting on payment of a fee, say £20, and placing a bond to maintain small service for one year, advertisements to he strictly limited, no charge whatever to public for the service, but would be on any wave length available, and under strict Radio Department's regulations.
That all receiving sets bought complete or made up of parts can be capable of receiving on any- wave lengths.
All dealers in wireless apparatus to be licensed and under penalties for supplying apparatus to others than holders of Government licences.
Licences to be obtained at post-offices or licensed dealers.

quote.para: Then broadcasting will have a chance to be on the proper lines, the public having six subsidized high-power stations at their service and a number of other stations supplied by firms, &c. (as in U.S.A. at present}, but properly supervised here, all for the sum of £3 3s. per annum. Just you calculate the money available by subscribers in each capital city, which would be at least £10,000 per State. Then the Minister, Mr. Gibson, could see his ' dream come true - Australia the only country in the world running broadcasting on proper lines.

talk.start.para: - Mr. Norris is quite satisfied now.
-'- It is strange, then, that he should have written me a second letter, dated 9th August.
- I had a deputation on Wednesday, 8th August, and Mr.. Norris saw me the next day and said that everything was all right.
- The letter I received from Mr. John Payne, editor of the Australasian Wireless Review, of Sydney, under date 6th August, is the following : -

quote.para: Wireless is one of the most revolutionary things that has happened in the century from the educational point of view, and from our point of view as Labour men we should do all in our power to further the coming of the benefits 'of this science into the homes to add a little brightness and happiness.
In the Old Country the wharfies has his little set, and listens in at night with his family. It keeps him at home, and the home is the brighter and happier for it.

There any one can have a radio receiving set to cover any wave length, and this means that he can listen in to all kinds of concerts from all over the place. In New Zealand splendid regulations have been gazetted, and any one there can have a receiver which will receive any wave length, and concerts are heard in different places from the North Cape to the Bluff, the annual licence fee being only 5s.

In England the listener-in to radio concerts, as they are called, pays £1 per year, 10s. of which goes to the Broadcasting Company, a company formed to render; radio service throughout Great Britain. In addition, amateurs send music. So far, a fee of only £1. An English radio man can listen to' any concert for that inclusive sum. In America there is absolute- freedom, as only an annual licence fee is charged by the Government of a nominal amount, and the big firms broadcast free for the purpose of advertisement mainly.

Our regulations have just been gazetted, as you will be aware, and they contain some of the most damnable and restrictive provisions on the radio concert listener it is possible to conceive. 1 have quoted sufficient to show that there is some dissatisfaction. The people which have corresponded with me understand the business. I do not know anything about radio-wireless, and am bringing the matter up because I have been requested to do so, and because the regulation,, I understand, will come into force on the 15th of this month. I hope that the Postmaster-General will see his way to suspend its operation until he has made further inquiries. I have personally no doubt that he has taken every care in the matter, but in the initiation of these things some little mistakes- are likely to occur. I agree with the honorable gentleman that it would be unwise to hold up the matter for any great length of time. The system should be introduced as quickly as possible. We should encourage companies to start radio services to give the people the benefit of them. I believe that advantage will be taken of the system by big business companies in the different cities to communicate information concerning their business to their customers. I believe it will he beneficial in many ways.' It is one of the great scientific developments of the last few years, and we should see that it is installed here. I realize that it would be futile to table an objection to the regulation at this stage, because it would be too late. This concerns people in the country districts. probably more than people in the city. In the cities people can go to places of amusement every night, but the residents of country districts scarcely ever near a concert, and cannot get in touch with the news of the outside world. The installation of the- radio services should assist to make the lives of country residents happier than they are to-day, and help them to spend their winter evenings more pleasantly than they can do now. I have been supplied with the regulations which it is desired to have. amended, but it is unnecessary to- refer to them here. Those who have communicated with me assure me that their one object in the matter is to make the radio service a success. I leave the subject at that. I am sure the Postmaster-General will give consideration to the representation I have made.

talk.start.para: .I want -to compliment the Postmaster-General upon the very concise way in which he presented his Department's programme. It is gratifying to honorable members who receive so many communications concerning postal .matters to know that every year the Post and Telegraph Department is modernizing as well as liberalizing its ideas. The fact is becoming prevalent that the Department is a public utility, and not merely a money-making concern. The expenditure upon it in the different States should not be on a per capita basis. When the Government recently proposed the appropriation of £500,000 for main roads development, they decided that it would be wrong to allocate the vote to the different States on a per capita basis, because it was obvious that the States in most need of the grant were those with the greater areas. The Government allocated a portion of the £500,000 on the per capita basis, and the balance on an area basis. I was pleased to learn the distribution which the Postmaster-General proposes for this year's expenditure in metropolitan and country areas. His advisers in Western Australia may not have properly estimated the amount which should be spent in that State. They failed to do so last year under Mr. Poynton'sregime, and, if that is the case this year, they will have to apply later on for increased expenditure. The Minister has admitted that he scarcely knows how to get through his programme and spend £4,000,000 in the year effectively. The honorable gentleman will find useful and proper ways of expending the money in Western Australia. I wish to say in the kindliest manner that "Western Australia - and I dare say the same thing applies to Tasmania and Queensland - suffers greatly because of its distance from the centre of things in

speech.para: Melbourne. The honorable member for Corio (Mr. Lister) was able to refer* the Minister to post-boxes in this street and that street in Geelong, but we cannot do that kind of thing in Western Australia. I hope that the Postmaster-General will, take advantage of the earliest opportunity to visit the various States, and that he will especially visit Western Australia. He will find that development is going on in that State. The State Government is trying to effect the settlement of immigrants on the land. The Commonwealth Government is paying part of the interest on the expenditure of a lot of money in that State for the purpose, and settlement is spreading rapidly into large new areas. We have been told many times in this chamber that if a block of land is put to the ballot in some of the States there will be 500 or 600 applicants for it. That is not the case in Western Australia. Although it may cost £5,000 per mile to lay cables in the cities, 100 miles might be laid for that money in Western Australia. I hope that during the recess the Postmaster-General will devote as much time as possible to visiting the various States in order to make himself acquainted with local conditions. The Postmaster-General, no matter who he is, must work largely through Deputies. Some Postmasters-General in the past have imposed very restrictive conditions. Officials' of the Department have been brought up under them, and have got into a groove. They want to be on the safe side, bust the Postmaster-General should let them know that regulations must be liberally interpreted. I hope the Postmaster-General, when he visits Western Australia, will not stay there for only a day or two.

talk.start.para: - I call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]

- We desire the 'Postmaster-General to visit Western Australia, so that he may be able to see some of the country areas and the conditions of the settlers, and by a personal chat with his officials imbue their minds with the reforms which he has been able to bring about elsewhere.
- I propose to do so.
- I am glad that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Charlton) mentioned the question of broadcasting.

speech.para: I do not know whether any errors ha.v been made in connexion with the regulations issued recently by the Postmaster-General, but when I showed him one communication from Western Australia he said that the complaint it contained was without foundation. However, wireless has come to stay, and it should be placed upon a sure and permanent basis. To ' avoid the risk of damages being claimed for loss sustained through plants having been purchased in accordance with departmental regulations and then being found unsuitable had to be varied, the regulations should be closely overhauled to insure that the Department is proceeding on absolute safe and sound lines. I conclude by' expressing my gratification that the Postmaster-General intends to visit the £>tate of Western Australia, the people of which sometimes feel that, because of their remoteness from Melbourne, they are almost outside the Federation and are overlooked.

talk.start.para: . - I, in common with other honorable members on this side, protest against the inadequate opportunity afforded us to discuss these most important expenditure proposals. ' The postal services are the most important rendered to the people by any Government Department. Yet not more than ten members in a House of seventy-five will have an opportunity to express their opinions concerning the administration of the Department. That is a scandalous state of affairs, particularly as during the next fortnight the House will be dealing with comparatively unimportant legislation. The expenditure indicated by the Postmaster-General will give a certain amount of relief during the next twelve months, but the last Government and the one preceding it had so neglected to keep pace with current requirements, and so starved some of the services, that even the new works and additions now promised will not be adequate if population increases as has been foreshadowed.
-THE war affected those services.

- Tt was not so much the war as the foolish cry for false economy that induced the Government to cut out many services. For instance, mail services in country districts were cut down from three to two a week, and in order to get back the old service the people are asked to dip their hands into their pockets to pay a subsidy. One town in a grazing district used to get three mail deliveries a week; the service was cut down to two mails a week, and the residents were informed that if they wished to restore the three-days-a-week service they must pay £70 per annum towards the additional cost. This Parlia-ment should make the Postmaster-General understand that such services should be paid for out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The people living in these outback districts are pioneers; "they are making the country habitable, and helping to support the people living in the cities. Yet, in addition to the taxation they pay, an additional impost is put upon them when they ask for a service to which they are entitled. People who settle in the country should not be penalized by being asked to put their hands into their pockets in order to pay for necessary conveniences. The people who go outback and open up the country are asked to pay more for postal and telegraphic services than are the men who stay in. the big centres of population.

speech.para: In regard to the expenditure upon works and buildings, I draw the attention of the Postmaster-General to the fact that there are many small but well-established villages, the population of which will' never be great enough to, justify the establishment of an official post office. These places are served by allowance officers, who are required to provide their own quarters. Is it right to ask these officers, who receive not more than from £2 to £3 per week, to pay for accommodation for themselves? There is in the town of Cobbadah an old tumble-down stone building, in which the postmistress has accommodation. She cannot be expected to provide better accommodation for herself when she is not secure in her position. She is told by ' the Department that it will not erect a building for her, although a timber room could be built for about £50. The policy of the Department should be to build offices and- quarters, and' charge small rents for them. The postmistress at Cobbadah pays 5s. per week for the rent of a room in a tumble-down building.
That would be a handsome return on the capital cost of a small wooden building.

Many employees of the Postal Department are inadequately remunerated for their services. There are some men who have been in the .Department for twenty-five and thirty years, are in control of as many as ten officers, and are responsible for a twenty-four-hours-a-day service. They have to handle large amounts of money, and to be in attendance at all hours of the day or night, and yet are receiving only £250 per annum, plus a living allowance.

talk.start.para: - And child endowment !

- Some of the men are up in years, and their families are already grown up; therefore they do not get the endowment. Unless the Department will pay better salaries it cannot expect to attract the best men to its service. Another injustice is in respect of the allowance to junior officers transferred to stations away from their homes. A boy of poor parents may be required by the Department to transfer to another office. If his father cannot afford to ' assist him, that boy, after having spent a couple of years in the Department, has to resign his position for no other reason than his father's poverty. That is not just. The total allowance in this regard this year for New South Wales is £4,010. I know of many boys who have been forced to leave their positions in the Department because they could not afford to be transferred. That is not the sort of treatment that should be given to young men who enter the Commonwealth service.

speech.para: The Postmaster-General has spoken of the large amount of money to be expended in connexion with telephone services. Until wireless has been simplified and cheapened, the telephone will continue to be the chief means of communication between people in the outback districts, and I appeal to the Postmaster-General to liberalize and broaden his policy with regard to telephones'. The Minister may say that Cabinet will not give him more money, but his duty is to come to Parliament and ask for the money. People in the country districts appreciate the value of the telephone, and as a result are often prepared to pay more than they can really afford to secure the convenience. Unfortunately, many are unable to provide the funds, and in case of sickness are at. a serious disadvantage as compared with their wealthier neighbours, though their people are just as near and dear to them. The 'Government, we- have been informed, have placed £2,500,000 to a contingency fund for defence. Probably this' money will be poured into the Singapore Naval Base. The Government, with the surplus funds at their disposal, should liberalize the postal and telegraphic and telephonic- services pf our people in the back country districts. The Postmaster-General will . not be able to carry out his public works policy during the next twelve months, unless he enlarges his staff. I suggest that steps be taken in this direction at once to insure that the much-needed facilities in country "districts shall be provided promptly, and a-t the same time relieve much of the unemployment iri our midst. The mail contractors are a class of persons who should be protected from themselves. In the past it has been customary to grant allowances to them during periods of drought,' and as a result some genius in the post office evolved the brilliant idea -of placing in the contract the provision that in future no. drought allowances were to be claimed. Of course, it was a ridiculous provision. If it were enforced the contractors would have to safeguard themselves by advancing their charges. They would have to provide for feed for at least eighteen months out of the three years. No man can possibly foreshadow the weather conditions in Australia over a series of years. I wish to be perfectly fair to the Minister. He states that his instructions have been misinterpreted, but I have received letters to the effect that a man whose contracts were not in existence prior to 1st July, 1922, would not be entitled to drought allowance.

talk.start.para: - My instruction applies to them all.

- I am glad to have the assurance of the Minister, and I hope he will get to work at once and see that these men receive the relief as' promptly as possible. I have in mind one man who has been carrying out a contract for fifteen years, and is suffering more severely from drought now than ever before.
- Every district must be dealt with on its merits.

- I hope the Minister will see that this ridiculous provision is eliminated from forms of tender, otherwise most mail tenders will have to be based on a much higher cost, because the contractor will have to safeguard himself against a period of possible drought, and thereby increase the cost of mail contracts. On the question of accommodation for the public and for employees in country districts, I think that there should be a thorough inspection, and re-organization of all our postal buildings with a view to bringing them up to date. Many are very inconvenient and badly lighted, and in several places where there is electric light the Department insists on retaining the old gas lighting system. In this matter we should follow the example of the States. As a rule, State public buildings are an ornament to a town or district, whereas a Commonwealth building is usually the most ramshackle structure in the town.
- We are dealing with 274 of them this year.

- Many hundreds more throughout Australia need attention. Many of them are dilapidated, unpainted, and, generally speaking, are no credit to the Commonwealth. Our electoral office, post-office, and branches of the Commonwealth Bank could, in many instances, be housed in one substantial and presentable building. I have in mind most unsuitable quarters at Narrabri, housing the electoral officer for the division of Gwydir. I propose to test the feeling of the Committee in regard to increasing the mail and telephone facilities in country districts. It has been urged that if these facilities are granted to one country centre, thousands of other districts will want the same treatment, and we may not have the money to provide them.
- We cannot spend the £8,000,000 in one year.

- I was not referring to works and. buildings, but to mail and postal services in country districts. We should not withhold these facilities from the people. On the contrary, it should be our duty to provide them wherever possible. Parliament is in control of the finances, and honorable members should give the Postmaster-General an intimation to re-draft his policy with a view to liberalizing the provisions in regard to mail contracts, and provide for mail contractors to call in at homesteads. As a case in point, I may state that many men have to ride from11/2 to 2 miles and even 5 miles every day from the homestead to the mail road on the off-chance that there may be an important letter for him. Where a person is within a reasonable distance of a mail route, or even if he is inconveniently situated, the Postmaster-General, should include terms in mail contracts requiring the contractors to run their services so as to suit the people. We should provide money so that country people shall not be obliged to travel long distances each mail day from week to week and month , to month to get their mails.
- Many of those people would object to the mailman carrying their letters loose.

- The mails are carried in bags which are dropped into the letter boxes and the addressee has to ride, very often several miles, on the chance that the mail may contain a letter for him. We should give these people in our back-country more liberal treatment. I move -

speech.para: That the proposed vote be reduced by £1.

I move this with a view to indicating to the Government that provision be made to provide better mail and telephone facilities in country districts, the cost to be borne by the Department. Why should we ask a subsidy of people for services which it is the duty of this Department to provide? The Postmaster-General is entitled to have an expression of opinion from honorable members on. this matter. If he had a definite intimation from honorable members upon this important subject, his hand would be strengthened with his colleagues in Cabinet. I believe many honorable members are in sympathy with my views. This amendment will give them an opportunity of registering their opinion. The amendment is not a censure motion. I submit it merely to give honorable members an opportunity of demonstrating where their sympathies lie in this matter. I have no doubt that I shall be met with the objection that it will entail certain expenditure that was not contemplated, but I submit that we should have a departmental contingency fund to meet the additional charges. We have gone back in the matter of mail services in many country districts. This retrograde step is not conducive to land settlement. Parliament should provide the money out of Consolidated Revenue for these improved facilities, and should not penalize the dwellers in our back-country areas.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 8.30 a.m. to 9. SO a.m. (Saturday).

talk.start.para: . - Much has already been said about the need for added postal facilities in country districts. While fully recognising that need, I wish to say something about the standard which should be aimed at, and which has not yet been attained, in the city and suburbs, where facilities are still sadly below what they ought to bo in a modern city.
- I admit that.

- In Melbourne there are only four deliveries per day in, the business centres, certainly not more. We ought to aim at a delivery and a clearance every hour in the business centre of a metropolitan city. Until we have that, , we shall not be up to th'e standard of a modern city. It is in the interests of the whole community that postal facilities should be ready, speedy, and reliable. I direct the attention of the Postmaster-General. by' way of example, to the position in the near-Melbourne suburbs in my constituency. At Glen Iris, which is six miles from the General Post Office, the final clearance is at 9 p.m., and at Burwood, eight miles away, at 8.35 p.m. In the whole of my electorate, which includes Kew up to Surrey Hills, along' the eastern suburbs lines, the average time of clearing may be said to be 10.15 p.m. In some cases it is 9.45, and in a few 11 o'clock. Some years ago the clearance used to be made very much later ; that is to say, the" postal facilities have gone backwards in recent years. The hour of 10.15 p.m. is too early for suburban clearances. . Deliveries are also very unsatisfactory. In a district in North Camberwell, the delivery is frequently not made :; until 12.30 - after mid-day ; that is the so-called morning delivery. There are other districts in my constituency which require further facilities. At Hartwell and South

speech.para: Camberwell there are no post-offices, which are badly needed, as are also telephone cabinets. Population in these districts has greatly increased and postal facilities have not kept pace. I call attention to these facts to show that a great deal still remains to be done in order to make the city and suburban services really efficient. The telephone service in Melbourne is still far from satisfactory, particularly after 6 o'clock at night, when it would appear' that the staff is considerably reduced, and it is difficult to obtain connexion. There is also a necessity for a parcels van to call for parcels ' of any weight.

The only other matter to which I desire to refer is one that has already been mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Charlton). I desire to support generally what that honorable gentleman said in regard to wireless, and to call particular attention to the fact that under the new regulations it is proposed to continue the issue, as in the past, of what are called experimenter's licences. Ordinary receiving licences, known as experimenter's licences, which give so much joy and pleasure, and afford so many opportunities for the acquisition of scientific knowledge to the younger portion of the community, and to many adults, are also to be issued as in the past. If that is done, there will not be any subscribers, from a practical point of view, to broadcasting companies that may be formed. The experimenter's licence entitles the licensee to have a receiving instrument which is adjustable to any wave length within its capacity. Th'e idea of the new regulations is that broadcasting companies should be licensed to operate on a certain wave length, and that receiving instruments' should be sealed to the wave length. Any person with an adjustable receiver will, however, be able to " listen in " to broadcasting. Accordingly, if the licences are to be . issued as in the past, it will be impossible for broadcasting companies to make a commercial success of their ventures. The Postmaster-General should hesitate before issuing any broadcasting transmitting licences under the regulations, which provide that the licensee shall deposit or give security for £1,000 in return for a licence for five years. At this early stage of broadcasting" it -would be dangerous to issue licences for so long a period. I urge on the Postmaster-General, as I did on another occasion, that these regulations be reconsidered in the interests of the public, and particularly in the interests of the development of broadcasting. These licences, I understand, are intended to assist that development, but there is grave reason to fear that they may have the opposite effect. The fee to be charged by the broadcasting licensee is not specified in the regulations, and the Minister has no power under the regulations to fix, limit, or restrict the fee in any way. It may be that the Minister may endeavour to 'do so as a matter of administration, but the regulations do not entitle him to take that course. The result is that, if a broadcasting licence were issued, a company, having made the deposit of £1,000, or lodged security to that amount, would be entitled to operate for five years, subject to conditions which are to be approved, but which relate only to the efficiency of the service. In the present state of knowledge in Australia, it is dangerous to accept a deposit and issue in return therefor a licence for that length of time. I hope that, in the interests of amateurs or experimenters, and in the. interests of the development of broadcasting, the regulations will be reconsidered.

talk.start.para: . - I congratulate the Postmaster-General (Mr. Gibson) on the able manner in which he placed his Estimates before the Committee. My own electorate has not very much to complain of, 'and I am sure that the Postmaster- General will do his best to provide the public with proper facilities. I should like some information as to the postal rates that are proposed for newspapers in bulk.
- I call attention to the want of a quorum. [Quorum formed. ,]
- I ask the Postmaster-General whether the postal charge on newspapers in bulk throughout the Commonwealth is to be reduced from l£d. to Id. ?
- I cannot make a statement at present, as a Bill is shortly to be introduced into the House affecting the postal rates on newspapers.
- I shall be able to obtain that information later?
- Yes.

, - Several grievances concerning the Postal Department have been submitted to me. In Perth at present there is no Saturday half-holiday, although this privilege exists in Melbourne. It is becoming generally recognized' throughout the Commonwealth and other civilized countries that shops and business places - -the opening of which on Saturday afternoons was formerly considered necessary - should now be closed every Saturday afternoon. As an example, I refer to the chemists' shops in the metropolitan area of Melbourne. As the Saturday half-holiday has not caused disorganization of postal arrangements in Melbourne and other capital cities of the Commonwealth where it applies, the same privilege should be given to Perth. There are few residents in the central portions of the city, and private persons wishing to transact business on Saturday afternoons could do so at suburban- offices. I ask' the Minister (Mr. Gibson) to consider' this suggestion from a broad and democratic stand-point.

speech.para: Under the Superannuation Act single men in the Postal Department are penalized, because no provision is made for dependants in case of the death, of those officers.

talk.start.para: - The Superannuation Board is working under the Act, and the postal administration has no control over it.

- The Act should be amended. I urge the Minister to bring this matter under the notice of the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce). In Western Australia the travelling allowance for linesmen has been reduced from 14s. 6d. to 13s. per day, and the Minister might well look into that matter.

speech.para: Another grievance concerns an old comrade of mine, named W. R. seery with whom I worked nearly thirty years ago> in the Perth Post Office. He has been in that. Department for thirty-four years. I can obtain later the full data for the Minister,, but, speaking from memory, a charge was laid against this man for an offence of which my knowledge of him leads me to believe he is incapable. A lady alleged that late one evening she walked into the Perth Post Office and handed to Mr. Seery a gold watch for parcel postage. According to the lady's version the parcel did not arrive at its destination in Adelaide, and it was alleged that the watch was afterwards disposed of by Mr. Seery's wife .in a secondhand shop. Although admitting that a gold watch was so disposed of by his wife, Mr. Seery claims that it was not the article in question. I acknowledge that on the face of it the evidence looks bad, but the case was tried by the Court, and Seery was exonerated. I have worked in the post-office mail room, and I know that there are in the community thousands of fools who enclose £5 notes in' unregistered letters and expect them to reach their destination. A number of postal officials have been arrested because, they have not been able to resist the temptation to appropriate letters containing money. This officer had passed through such a fiery ordeal for thirty-four years, and had never had a charge laid against him. It would, therefore, be a most peculiar thing if he succumbed to temptation in this instance. Of course, we know of cases where nien who have gone straight all their lives have suddenly given way to temptation. The Court, however, dismissed the charge that was laid against Seery. The Postal Department desired that Seery's case should first be dealt with at a departmental inquiry. His lawyer rightly adopted the attitude that Seery's interests would be .prejudiced if that course were followed and the departmental board condemned him. I know of men who have been adjudged guilty by departmental inquiries on evidence that would not stand investigation by a Court of law. In Kalgoorlie, on one occasion., during the hot weather a number of highly valuable stamps cracked across the centre as though they had- been cut with a pair of scissors, and men who had had ten, fifteen, and twenty years' service were suspended and harassed for months because the Department held ' the view that they had been piecing stamps together. Big Government Departments cannot be run like an ordinary business concern. The Service becomes centralized, despite every effort to prevent it. Correspondence assumes big proportions, and it is sometimes a simple matter to build up a case against an officer who may be perfectly innocent. Seery, in order to have his case first dealt with by the Court, undertook to forgo his salary during the period of his suspension. Had he not done so, he would not have been permitted to have his case dealt with by the Court prior to the holding of the departmental inquiry. As the result of the ordeal through which he has passed his nerves have been shattered. He has been reinstated. Number 270a of the Public Service regulations provides that where an officer has been suspended for an offence, and the charge has been found to be not proven, full pay for the period of suspension . shall dc allowed. Seery, because of the undertaking he was obliged to give in order that his case might be dealt with by the Court before being submitted to a Board of Inquiry, has not been paid for the time during which he was under suspension. I hope that the Postmaster-General (Mr. Gibson) will review the decision.

talk.start.para: . - Until recently there were no- regulations governing the broadcasting of wireless. Australia has, perhaps, done less than any other country in this direction. I hold the opinion that in the near future wireless will play a big part in the transmission of news. It would be a very great mistake to allow it to be made the plaything of children, and to prevent its having its' full commercial value. The .action which I took in regard to broadcasting was exactly similar to that which was taken by New Zealand, Great Britain, and some other countries. A conference was held of those interested in the broadcasting of wireless. Very many requests were made to me to convene such a Conference, and I did so. Sufficient time was given to those interested in the matter to attend the Conference. It was a most representative gathering, practically every State and every interest being represented. Those very people who are now complaining to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Charlton) and to the honorable member for Kooyong (Mr. Latham) were amongst the delegates to the Conference, and took their part in the framing of the regulations. Because .they believe there is some little difference between the regulations as issued and those that were agreed to, they are now asking for their amendment. The Conference sat for two days, and a committee was appointed on which these dissatisfied persons had a representative. That committee adopted the very regulations that we now have before us. In receiving the regulations from the Conference I asked, " Is the Conference unanimous in regard to these regulations ? " Not a solitary objection was voiced. I then said, " You absolutely surprise me. I expected some of you, at all events, to object to some portions of these regulations. I have adopted the attitude which was adopted by the British Government, and if these regulations are a failure the responsibility will rest on your shoulders and not on mine." This subject has given me more thought than any that I have tackled since ' I have been administering the Postal Department. Misleading statements have been made in regard to the application of these regulations to broadcasters who propose to erect stations for the purpose of broadcasting. It is quite true that under the regulations a person will be required to have a sealed set. It might just as well be urged that any boy in the street should be given the privilege of making a connexion with a telephone wire and listening to the messages that pass over the telephone, as that he should be allowed to listen in when messages or entertainments are being broadcasted at very great expense. We have arranged to regulate in the direction of having broadcasting stations licensed. As the honorable member for Kooyong said, a guarantee of good faith has to be given to the extent of £1,000. If this were not done there would be a number of "wild cat" schemes organized. Subscriptions would be charged, instruments would be sold to the people, and thousands of pounds would be collected. Then the whole scheme might 'be closed down, and no broadcasting done. A guarantee is now given to_ the people who subscribe that a service will be given, but there is in no sense a monopoly. We have received several applications for licences to broadcast, and no subscription whatever is to be charged. I ask honorable members not to condemn the regulations until they have been tried.
