speech.para: They are not like the laws of- the Medes and the Persians; they can be altered until we obtain regulations that will satisfactorily govern the broadcasting of wireless.

I hope that the honorable member for Gwydir (Mr. Cunningham) will withdraw his amendment, seeing that the policy of the Government is sympathetic towards the mail-carriers to whom ..-the honorable member has referred. The amount for the mail contracts in New South Wales has been increased by £19,000, and the vote for the whole of the Stages, independent of the carting of mails by railways, has been augmented by £33,568.

talk.start.para: .- I- call attention to the sum of £41,000 provided for meal allowances, and I emphatically protest against the regulations that have been drawn up by the Public Service Board. Regulation 68 states -

quote.para: Where an officer whose ordinary hours of duty are between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. is required to attend for duty before 6.30 a.m., or to remain on duty after 6.30 p.m., and where an officer is required to commence duty at least two hours before the usual time, or to remain on duty at least two hours beyond the usual time, and such attendance necessitates his obtaining a meal away from home, he shall be granted a meal allowance according to salary on the following scale : -

speech.para: I take ' it that the men in the lower grades should receive the same meal allowance as the Deputy Postmaster-General, or any other highly-paid official. Probably, if justice were done, the low salaried man would receive more than those above him. Is it thought that an officer -receiving £750 a year requires more sustenance than an officer beneath him, who probably has to do heavier work, or does the Board consider that the higher the salary received by- an officer the more he should receive by way of meal allowance to enable him to have a more expensive meal ? The allowance should at least be uniform.

talk.start.para: - I shall put the matter before the Prime Minister.

- I hope the Government will not shelve their responsibility by saying that it is a matter for the Public Service Board. Honorable members should protest against such glaring anomalies as one officer receiving twice the allowance granted to another.

speech.para: The amount on the Estimates for the Postal Institute in New South Wales is £1,064. I understand that an officer has been appointed to attend to the accounts of the Institute, and if my information is correct he receives an allowance for that work. Seeing that there are great numbers of returned soldiers and others out of employment, would it not be better to create a new position rather than allow an officer already in receipt of a good salary to have an extra allowance for additional work i

Another matter to which I desire briefly to refer can be quickly indicated by the following extract from a letter I have received from the secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Postal Electricians Union -

quote.para: The costly and cumbersome costing system, and the staffing of the professional division in our branch, are making the overhead charges so heavy that equipment that should be manufactured locally is in a number of instances imported.

speech.para: These heavy charges result in increasing the cost of manufacture in Australia. It is most unfair to the workmen employed in the Department that their labour costs should be over-burdened to such an extents- thus causing much material to be imported which could otherwise be manufactured in Australia.

talk.start.para: . - I ask the Postmaster-General to consider, in connexion with the new Postal Rates Bill, which will be introduced this session, the question of reducing the telegraphic rate. The present charge for Inter-State messages is Id. per word, with a minimum charge of ls. 4d. Much time would be saved to officers of the Department if the minimum charge was reduced to ls. Some consideration might also be given to a proposal to charge varying rates for Inter-State messages. At the present time it 'costs as much to send a telegram from Wodonga to Albury as from Port Darwin to Townsville, via, Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, and Rockhampton. I suggest that the charges should be based on a zoning system.
- Might not the adoption of that suggestion involve increases in certain instances?

- I do not think it would be necessary to make any increases. On the contrary, the suburban rate might be reduced to 6d., at which it previously stood. The facilities for lodging lettergrams should also be extended. These are now accepted only at the head office. Why should they not be accepted at every suburban office, so that residents of the suburbs might enjoy the same facilities in this respect as people in the cities? They are handed in as deferred telegrams, and despatched whenever a clear line is available. In some offices the slack period is in the middle of the day; in others, it is in-' the afternoon. As suburban offices close at 6 p.m., this facility could very easily be granted. 1 also desire to urge the establishment of an exchange at Lakemba. I do not wish to encroach upon the electorate of the honorable member for Reid (Mr. Coleman), but the people on the Belmore railway line are united in their desire for this exchange. In the Canterbury municipality alone there are nearly 50,000 ratepayers, and they are unable to get a telephone exchange, and along the Belmore line there are approximately 1,000 subscribers, and there would be more if the exchange were provided. An extra rate is charged to these people because they live more than a certain distance from the Ashfield, Burwood, and Homebush Exchanges. Such treatment of people in a thickly populated area is not fair, and, moreover, the absence of an exchange is not economical for the Department. If an exchange were provided money could be saved, and subscribers given much more efficient service. I hope, also, that the Minister will give further consideration to the request for the establishment of a post-office at Hurlstone Park. This office is very much needed in the interests of a thickly populated area.*

. - I wish to bring under the notice 'of the Postmaster-General the miserable remuneration given to those people who run allowance post-offices in the country. Those in control of semi-official offices complain bitterly of what happens to them when they build up an office to official status. They suddenly find themselves without a job. That kind of treatment is unfair to people who are in charge of semi-official offices, and discourages them from putting forward their best efforts in the interests of. the Department and the public. I bring the matter under the notice of the Postmaster-General in the hope that he will do something to see that men who give their time and energy to the building up of these offices will not be thrown out of employment because of their success. I have received several complaints of this character. Then there are the allowance offices. I know the stereotyped answer of the Department to requests for increased allowances to the persons in charge of these offices. It is pointed out that allowance post-offices are given only to persons who have another business. There are many places, particularly small places out-back, where it is not possible to run any other' business in conjunction with an allowance office. They have to be at the beck and call of the public, not only during ordinary office hours, but at all times. A huge institution like the Post Office, which is showing a large profit, should do something to improve the conditions of these people.

speech.para: While I am thankful for small mercies, and admit that the Postmaster-General is doing something to meet the position, there is still a grievance in country districts that the greater proportion of the money voted for new works is spent in city areas. Last year £58,462 was spent in the country in New South Wales as against £244,429 in the -city areas. A sum of £1,400 was to have been expended on a new building at Wagga. The existing post-office building is a disgrace to such a place, which is one of the best towns between Sydney and Melbourne. In the Estimates this year a sum of only £500 is provided. The postmaster is compelled to live in. a hotel, where he cannot afford to keep his wife and family, and because of the want of quarters they have to live in Sydney. I give that instance to show that fair treatment is not being given to the country districts. As I desire to test the Committee on this question, I give notice of my intention to move -

quote.para: That the proposed vote be reduced by 10s.

speech.para: I shall move that amendment to indicate to the Government that provision should be made for more liberal payments to officers in charge of semi-official and allowance offices.

On behalf of the honorable member for Brisbane (Mr. D. Cameron), who is absent by leave of the House, I wish to bring under the notice of the Postmaster-General the urgent necessity for remodelling the post-office at Brisbane. There are also important suburbs of the city in which allowance offices inadequately cater for the needs of the people. In my own electorate, Lilley, application for official offices to take the place of allowance offices have been made from places like Nundah and Hamilton. The suburb of Windsor, which contains something like 15,000 inhabitants, has special claims for immediate consideration. ' I hope these matters will be attended to in the near future. I "congratulate the Minister on having effected some reforms that have been urged for long years past, particularly on the decision to allow State engineers to expend larger sums than hitherto on their own responsibility. This will result in a great saving of time and increased convenience to the public.

I direct attention to the urgency of providing the full amount required for the construction of a post-office and telephone exchange in Lakemba, New South Wales. This is a matter of mutual interest to the honorable member for Parkes (Mr. Marr) and myself. We are inundated with complaints of the inconvenience caused by the congestion of the lines in that district. The paltry sum of £500 is placed on the Estimates towards the cost of con- 'struction of the exchange, the total estimated cost of which is £3,660. It is also' important that the-full amount necessary to complete the construction of the Belmore and Guildford post-offices should .be provided. I regret that greater opportunity is not given to discuss the hundreds of complaints I have received.

talk.start.para: .. - I ask the Postmaster-General (Mr. Gibson) to hurry on with the building of the long-promised and overdue post-offices in my electorate. I cannot say I am pleased at the small amount set down on account of the poSt-office in Bay-street, North

speech.para: Brighton. The site is a most valuable one, and ought to be utilized; an'd the people are extremely anxious to have the office completed. At Carnegie, and particularly at Oakleigh, there are excellent sites available, and I trust the work of building will be expedited.

talk.start.para: . - I regret very much that we have not considerably more time in which to discuss these Estimates, because, no doubt, valuable suggestions1 could be made that would assist the Postmaster-General (Mr.

speech.para: Gibson) in removing some of the anomalies of administration. I impress on the honorable gentleman the .necessity for extended postal and telephonic facilities in country districts. I am in accord with the amendment moved by the honorable member for Gwydir (Mr. Cunningham). I give the Postmaster-General credit for an earnest desire to help honorable members in their efforts to see that the needs of the people are not neglected. Much more generous consideration is required in the case of mail f contractors and those in charge of allowance offices.

The mail contractors are given an insufficient forage allowance, and allowance postmasters and postmistresses are much underpaid. I have no time to deal with these matters in detail, but I strongly protest against the action of the Department in compelling people who live on the outskirts of towns 'to subscribe something like £20 towards the expense of a daily mail delivery. I know several instances of the kind, and I am certain honorable members agree that the public should not be penalized in this way while postal 'rates are being reduced to benefit the big commercial houses in the cities. I urge the importance of cheaply constructed telephone lines in country centres. I believe the Postmaster-General himself favours them. For country districts we do not require extensions costing £60 per mile, but merely cheap lines sufficient for the needs of isolated districts. I have received a complaint from Brisbane, regarding mails for North Queensland. Second class mail matter, which is carried by sea from Brisbane, is often detained in the metropolis awaiting a contract boat north because the Department objects to paying the charges of a non-contract boat. This is very unfair to North Queensland. Perhaps the Minister will be good enough to peruse the speeches which have been made, and look" into the matter. Another complaint is of the great congestion at the Brisbane Post Office. I understand that the honorable member for Lilley (Mr. Mackay) and the honorable member for Oxley (Mr. Bayley) are looking after the interests of the honorable member for Brisbane (Mr. D. Cameron), and I shall have a conversation with these gentlemen with a view to removing this source of inconvenience. I am informed that the mails for Rockhampton have missed the train at times because of. the congestion. It is said that the office is understaffed, and that the employees labour under all kinds of disabilities, rendering the service by no means efficient. Mails are sometimes delayed for a fortnight or three weeks, according to definite inside information, which I shall hand over to the Postmaster-General. There is another little matter I should like to mention. Under the old Public Service Act,, females employed in the Postmaster-General's Department were given a special allowance on their retirement in case of marriage. When the Bill to amend the Act was before this House I think provision for a continuance of this practice was inadvertently omitted. As a result, the Department has sent out a circular to the female employees, stating that no such payment will be made on and after the date of the proclamation of the Act. I ask the Minister to look into this matter and have it rectified.

talk.start.para: - The time has arrived for the question to be put.

- This is an outrage on representative and responsible government. Time after time I have tried, without success, to get the call from the Chair. I do not blame, the Temporary Chairman, but I must enter my protest against this treatment of the representatives of the people of Australia. We might as well retire from the Committee.

division.header.para: Question - That the proposed vote be reduced by £1 (Mr. Cunningham's amendment) - put. The Committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: - There is not a line on the Estimates for the West Adelaide suburban telephone exchange in South Australia.

subdebate.1.para: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.There can be no discussion at this stage.

division.header.para: Question - That the proposed vote (Postmaster-General's Department, £7,997,131) be agreed to- put. The Committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: - Will the Chairman now take my amendment?

- The honorable member for Hume gave notice of his intention to move a further amendment relating to the Postmaster-General's Department. As it was impossible for him to press his amendment while another amendment was before the Chair, and as the time allotted- for the discussion of Estimates of that Department expired at 10.30 a.m., it cannot be considered.

- On a point of order, I grant that when the time has expired the discussion is closed, but it then becomes the duty of the Chairman to put to the Committee every motion which has been moved or consequential motions of which notice has been given. The honorable member for Hume having given notice of an urgent amendment, it now becomes the duty of the Committee, as they cannot discuss the motion, to at least register an opinion upon it. 1 suggest that procedure, Mr. Chairman, for your earnest consideration, and I hope that you will give a sound and independent judgment.
- For the benefit of the honorable member for Batman and other members of the Committee, I call their attention to stand- . ing order 262A. (VI.), which reads -

quote.para: For the purpose of bringing to a conclusion any proceedings which are to be brought to a conclusion on the expiration of the time allotted under any motion passed under any of the preceding paragraphs of this standing order, the Speaker or the Chairman shall at the time appointed under the motion for the conclusion of those proceedings, put forthwith the question on any amendment or motion already proposed from the Chair, and, in the case of the consideration of any Bill in Committee, shall then put any clauses, and any Government amendments and new clauses and schedules, copies of which have been circulated by the Government among members two hours at least before the expiration of the allotted time, and any other question requisite to dispose of the business before the House or Committee. No other amendments, new clauses, or schedules shall be proposed.

speech.para: Department of Health.
Proposed vote, £137,296.
War Services Payable out of Revenue.
Proposed vote, £989,916.

talk.start.para: . - I do not find fault with the. reduction in the amount proposed to be expended by the Department of Health this year if it is not to be at the expense of the health of the community. The population is growing. We know that various diseases and malignant growths have increased. We are bringing large numbers of immigrants to Australia every month, some of whom it is alleged require medical attention. If money can be saved without an injurious effect on public health it will be all right. The estimated expenditure in connexion with war pensions this year is £7,000,000. The expenditure last year was £7,134,967. There is thus a very substantial decrease. It is a good thing if men have recovered and are no longer entitled to a pension; but if the reduction is due to the fact that the pension is being taken from men who are unable to follow their usual employment and are not able to earn the same amount of money that they earned prior to enlistment, it is a step in the wrong direction. We should not adopt a cheeseparing policy. Returned soldiers are endeavouring to have the Pensions Act liberalized. I think they have a very just claim. They want medical attention to be given to the widows and orphans of the soldiers who have fallen. That will hot mean a very heavy expenditure. Surely Parliament can make provision for medical attention to be available to women who have been left with little ones, in order that they may not be called upon to deplete their scanty income. There is a section of the men whom the doctors have certified to be permanently incapacitated and not likely to be again in a condition to do any work. They are receiving the full pension. Another section - those who are totally incapacitated and unable to work - do not receive the full pension. That distinction should not exist. If men are totally incapacitated and are unable to follow their employment, surely they should be entitled to receive the full pension. A couple of years ago I expressed dissatisfaction with the Boards which had been appointed to deal with these cases. I do not think any honorable member will contend that a distinction should be drawn between men who are totally incapacitated and those who are certified to be permanently incapacitated. If a man cannot work for twelve months surely he should be given the full pension for that period. Parliament never intended to make any difference between these men. Representatives of the returned soldiers waited on me this week and assured me that this distinction exists, and that men who are totally incapacitated are not receiving the full pension. The sooner the Minister sees that this anomaly is rectified the better. There is another section of men whose incapacity is estimated at about 65 per cent. Those poor unfortunate men cannot get work. The employers who will give work to a man who is 65 per cent, incapacitated are few and far between. They want to get as much work as possible for the money they pay, and they look for able-bodied men. These poor fellows are given a reduced pension, which they are unable to supplement. The pensioner in many cases has a wife and children. There is no doubt that the Government of the day made a. mistake in not paying war gratuities in cash. At that time Australia was borrowing money at 5 per cent. Had the amount of the gratuity been borrowed the cost to the Commonwealth would not have been as great as it has been, because it would not have been necessary to establish ' additional Departments. Those soldiers who were given cash put it into a business or a home.
- Many of them are anxious to re-invest -in Commonwealth stock

- Those who could afford to invest in Commonwealth stock did so, and they are willing to re-invest it now. That proves that they are a thrifty class of men. In connexion with the payment of war gratuities, it is expected that the expenditure this year will be £12,000. Last year £23,744 was paid out on that account. I suppose the total expenditure under that head will be from £50,000 to £60,000. This amount could have been saved had cash been given instead of bonds. I hope that the Treasurer will pay the gratuities at the earliest possible moment. Dr. Earle Page. - They are all due next May.

- I know that. The expenditure this year on loan conversion, it is' estimated, 'will be £50,000. Last year £183,635 was expended. That is a very heavy expenditure on a loan of £17,000,000. If a similar expenditure occurs whenever loans are converted, the cost of those loans will be added to considerably. I take it the only loan to be converted this year will be that which is now on the market. The conversion may cost, a good deal more than the £50,000 estimated. The strange thing is that the flotation of loans to-day costs considerably more than it did during the war. That should not be the case. It is about time that something was done to minimize this expenditure. The interest this year on loans for war purposes will amount to £12,227,872. Last year £12,187,604 was expended in that direction. The increase this year is, therefore, £40,268. That plainly shows that the cost is becoming greater with the maturing of every fresh loan. In the past it was argued that the rate of interest would drop a couple of years after the cessation of hostilities. The facts' show, however, that the cost is increas-ing. In a couple of years' time many millions will have to be borrowed, and that will mean the addition of £100,000 or £200,000 to our interest bill, quite apart from the interest on any further loans floated in the mean-" time. Those figures are startling. Provision has been made to liquidate the national debt in fifty years. I do not think that that will be possible. - Unless something is done to check this unnecessary expenditure, it is difficult to imagine what the position will be ten years hence. It will certainly be much more acute unless a radical change is quickly effected. Under the "War Gratuity Act, we paid last year £1,128,249 in interest, and this year the interest will amount to £1,120,000, a decrease of only £8,249. My view is that the gratuities should all be paid in cash.
- Where is the money to come from?

- Money has been provided for many other items of expenditure and the war gratuities should have been paid off long ago. They were offered to the returned soldiers at the time of an election for the sordid purpose ' of securing their votes. I ask the honorable member for Martin (Mr. Pratten) if, with his knowledge of finance, he does not think it would have been cheaper if we had obtained the money when it was available at 5 per cent. We are now paying 5-J per cent! for it, but the saving of i per cent would have covered the cost of flotation, and the. Commonwealth would have been saved the expense of conducting the department that now deals with the gratuities. I feel sure that we could have borrowed the money at the time at 5 per cent. The whole trouble is that no attempt was made' to raise the money. The Government was' prepared to offer the bonds and let the soldiers wait. Now, however, the soldier. instead of being paid in cash, has to wait, and the public purse has suffered in consequence, because we have been maintaining a department that would not have been necessary if the bonds had been cashed. The time has arrived when the Repatriation Department should be closed down as far as the payment of pensions is concerned. This work could be better administered by the Invalid and Old-age Pensions Department, which gave the soldiers a better deal during the period when it was attending to the payment of their pensions.
- I do not look upon the administration of the pensions system by the Repatriation Department as particularly good at present.

- A considerable saving in money would result , from its abolition. Such departments were rendered necessary by the war, but as the expenditure is now decreasing, it would be economical to transfer the work to another department, especially in view of the fact that a more satisfactory deal would then be received by the soldiers. If we paid off the war gratuities we could save £50,000 or £60,000 per annum by abolishing the Repatriation Department.
- Would that not swell the ranks of the unemployed ?

- We ought to be able to absorb most of the officers now engaged in the Repatriation Department. If we could not employ them they should be compensated. It will be necessary to put off a number of men as a result of the policy of curtailing the operations of the Federal taxation offices, but no doubt many of the employees in that Department will- be engaged by the State Taxation Departments. " I am quite satisfied that very little money will be saved to the taxpayers under the new -scheme. Under the new arrangement the States will have to collect more money, and a larger number of men than they now employ will be required. It would be a good plan for the Treasurer to get into touch with the, various State Governments, and ascertain how many additional men will be needed.
- The abolition of a Federal Department would naturally throw men out of employment ; and work, according to honorable members opposite, cannot be found for the present unemployed.
- Yet the honor- able member is prepared to vote at any time for an expenditure of millions to bring immigrants to Australia.
- The immigrants will go into the country .districts.

- The solution of the difficulty is to make work available for the unemployed. No potential wealth producer should be permitted to remain idle, but expenditure should be cut down where that can legitimately be done. We should conduct the affairs of the country just as we would our private businesses. Personally, I do not think the work of collecting Federal taxes should be given to the State authorities. The Federal Parliament should be supreme in these matters.
- But we could not get the States to agree.
- The States placed us in the position of making us "feed out of their hands."
- That is not a fair statement of the position^

- It is exactly what happened. .The last Conference of State and Federal Ministers was as great a failure as any ever held, but the Government had to make it appear that some good had emanated from it.

.I desire to draw attention to the administration of the Repatriation ' Commission. Full power to . interpret the various sections of the War Pensions Act was given to the Commissioners, and the Treasurer under whose department the matter falls has, I understand, no power to alter a decision of the Commissioners without an amending Act or a strong intimation from Parliament. Every honorable member is desirous that the promises made by Parliament to the returned soldiers shall be carried out to the letter. The definition section of the War Pensions Act states that " dependants " includes " the parents of any such person who are, at any time after the occurrence of the event resulting in his death, without adequate means of support." Section 2 makes a pension payable on the death of a soldier provided that -

item.label: (a)
item.para: A claim for payment of a pension in accordance with this Act is made -

item.label: (i)
item.para: in case of the death of a member of the Forces - by a dependant not more than six months after the date of the public notification by- the Minister in the Gazette of the death of the member, except in the case of parents who though not dependent upon the earnings of the member at the time of his death are at any time without adequate means of support.

speech.para: Let me .bring under the notice of honorable members one of many instances. The only' son in a family, went to thewar and was killed. At that time the parents were' in a sound position. They were supposed to be wealthy, and no application whatever was made for a. pension. Later on the father died and. his estate was found to be insolvent. ] The mother was left with a little over £1,000, which to-day has diminished to £900. I advised her to apply for a war pension, and she did so, but was told that one could . not be granted to her; but that had her husband died within three years of her boy, she could have obtained one, even though she had an income of £1,000 a year. Her income is about £40 a year. She was formerly in good circumstances, and is about fifty-seven or fifty-eight years of age. The Department said to her, " We cannot give you a pension while you have the money. Spend the money, and then come to us, when we shall be able to give you a pension." According to the Commissioner she has to become a pauper before she is eligible for a pension. I have asked the' Department to define what it means by " adequate means of support." The Act is quite clear in its intention that any person who is without adequate means of support at any time after the death of his son while on active service, may, although perhaps not dependent upon him at the time of his death, apply for a pension. To show how carelessly the question has been thought out, I may instance a statement by a Commissioner, who said to me, " Have you ever heard of a person being arrested for not having adequate means of support, although he had £100 in his pocket?" People are arrested, not for not having " adequate means of support," but for not having " visible means of support." The Department contends that a person who possesses £100 or over does not come within the definition of £he section. I would go so far as to say that no person should receive a pension if be was in receipt of more than a certain sum. If a person was in receipt of, say, £150 a year, the Commissioners would be justified in saying that he' had adequate means of support, but the. woman to whom I have referred, who has an income of only £40 a year, has not adequate means of support. I have advised her not to follow the advice of the Commissioners and spend her money. The Treasurer (Dr. Earle Page) is fully aware of. the position. In other circumstances I would have proposed a reduction of the item, not with a view to embarrassing the Government, but to get Parliament to express to the Commissioners an opinion regarding what Parliament desires. I content myself, however, with bringing the matter under the notice of honorable members, so that pressure may be brought to bear upon the Commissioners to induce . them to carry out the intention of Parliament, which was that if, in the opinion of the Commissioners, a person had not adequate means of support - that is, a yearly income which would provide fair and reasonable conditions of living - : a pension should be granted. The adoption of the suggestion would, I admit, involve the Government in additional expenditure. There are other instances similar to those I have cited. I know of an engineer who went to the front with his son. The son was killed, and the engineer died' and left only £800 worth of life assurance policies to his wife. She applied for a pension and was told that she had adequate means of support. Parliament, when it passed the Act, . did not intend that the possession of that small amount of ready money should be regarded as " adequate means of support." I am not asking for anything new, but merely for what Parliament deliberately placed' in an Act. The action of the Commissioners is contrary to the intentions of Parliament, and is wholly unjust. I leave the matter there, hoping that the Government and Parliament will take action later.

talk.start.para: . - I wish, with due consideration for the claims of other honorable members, to say only a few words before the debate is closed. A very large number of important questions arise in connexion with this vote. Although it comes necessarily at "the fag end of the discussion of the Estimates, it would be a mistake to assume that it is comparatively unimportant. Possibly it is a phase of the Estimates which, from many points of view, is of the greatest importance. Under this heading we could quite properly have initiated a discussion on a matter which may come up in another way, but which cannot be too frequently or fully discussed in this Chamber; I refer, to the question of the War Service Homes..
-The honorable member will have an opportunity to debate that subject on the Loan Bill to be introduced next week.

- I cannot forget that the Treasurer told me something similar in connexion with other matters in the Estimates, and I am not over impressed with his promises, because I do not think he is quite clear as to the measure of time that will be allowed to the House.
- There will also be a War Service Homes Amending Bill.

- I appreciate the fact that an amending Act is promised; but it may or may not be discussed. The question might very advantageously, and very properly, have been opened up on the discussion of the Estimates. I say no more than that for the present, but I wish to lose no opportunity to deal with the subject. In the electorate which I have the honour tq represent there is a very large number of occupants of War Service Homes, and they have many just complaints. I have been asked to introduce a deputation next week in connexion with the matter, which, as every one knows, is a ,most complicated one. There is scarcely a member of Parliament who does not desire to bring individual cases under notice.

speech.para: A very informative address on the question of national health was given in this Committee by the honorable member for Darling (Mr. Blakeley), and I venture to express regret that no representative of the Ministry has made any statement upon a subject of such importance. Although we labour under many disadvantages in having this Government," we have an advantage in the fact that it includes as Treasurer an eminent medical man. I am quite prepared to concede that much. He is a ' man who, in the pursuit of his profession, has rendered very distinguished services to the community. I make that declaration apart from political considerations. I suggest that it would have been appropriate if Parliament had had the advantage of his advice and assistance in connexion with the question of health. One phase of health is the much-debated Spahlinger treatment for tuberculosis. I am very much interested in that, and in the meagre newspaper reports regarding the extent to which it is being tested. At times I have felt deep disappointment by reason of the fact that the Government was apparently regarding this alleged cure luke warmly, if not indifferently. Such an attitude, is not fair to the people of the Commonwealth. Tuberculosis is a dread disease, and if, by the expenditure o* a few thousand pounds - nay, I would say millions of pounds - we could introduce a reliable corrective to the dread bacillus, we would be spending money wisely, and in a direction that would have the support of every member of Parliament. I can merely "mention those two or three matters, and there are a host of others which might well have been discussed under the same heading had time permitted. I want to allow other honorable members a few minutes for discussion before the time limit is reached. I conclude, as I began, with a public protest against the way in which the Estimates have been handled and Parliament has been treated by the Government.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to state very plainly . the Government's attitude on the question of health. I listened very attentively to the able speech delivered the other day by the honorable member for Darling (Mr. Blakeley). The subject on which he spoke should be ventilated much more than it is. His speech was a distinct contribution to the discussion of national health, and that discussion might easily be added to from many other sources. The Government is anxious, and has shown itself very desirous, of proceeding with a national health policy, but its activities are very much hampered by the fact that it cannot bring the States into line. At the Premiers' Conference the Government put forward proposals, and pressed the States very hard, to assist us with expert advice in forming a Royal Commission to investigate the whole question, and define definitely the spheres of the Commonwealth Government, the State Governments, and the municipal authorities. The most we could do was to obtain 'the consent of the States to their public health officers discussing the matter with the ' Commonwealth health officer, after which the States would consider the representations made by those officers. The Government has endeavoured to arrange that conference. I have repeatedly urged that it should be held, but we have not been able to arrange it up to the present. As soon as that conference takes place I am hopeful that we shall

speech.para: Estimates, be able to have a Royal Commission, so that by this time next year we shall be able to adopt a definite line of action, and go straight ahead with a national health policy. This should lead not only to a discussion of the health of the community, but also to the adoption of measures to prevent the spread of disease, which, as was shown by the late war, can be done on a big scale. The difficulty we have had with the States explains why the proposed vote is almost the same as that for last year.

Regarding tuberculosis and the possibility of discovering a cure, the Govern- merit's position is quite plain. If it could see with any certainty a definite cure for that disease, or any process that would markedly alleviate and lessen the effects of it in the community, it would pay almost any price, and think that price cheap, to secure such a benefit. The Government is quite in the dark regarding the merits of the Spahlinger cure. We have sent representatives abroad, but they have not been able to obtain the information we desire. It is nob the Government's duty to "buy a pig in" a poke."

talk.start.para: - Some private practitioners have given some useful information.

- The Government has tried to get official and definite statements to enable it to determine whether the process is worth purchasing by the Government. During a previous debate, honorable members mentioned some undoubtedly hard cases amongst soldiers who are suffering from ill-health. Of course, the medical histories of these men are confidential, and it would be unfair to the patients to have the facts recorded in Hansard simply on the ground that they are in receipt of pensions. However, I have gone personally into each of the cases, and I have made the suggestion that a sub-committee consisting df soldier members of the House, one from each of the three parties, be appointed to make the necessary inquiries. If the suggestion is adopted we shall feel assured that the men .will receive just and sympathetic treatment.
- Will full effect be given to the recommendations of such a committee?
- That is a matter which could ' be discussed with the

speech.para: committee ; as I have said I do not think we are justified in discussing such cases on the floor of the House, and thus placing on record facts which might be read by the descendants of these men. No attempt whatever has been made to diminish the war pensions, nor has there been any falling-away in the sympathy which 0 is extended to the recipients. Many of these men are- extremely ill, and some of them, unfortunately, die. That is one" way, of course, in which the total expen"diture tends to diminish. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Charlton) referred to the necessity for medical treatment for embarrassed widows and children. The Government is going into that matter very carefully, and I hope to be able during the next week to suggest to the House any amendment of the Act that may be considered necessary. However, we may be able to accomplish what we desire by means of regulation.

The cases of incapacity may be divided into two classes. There is, in the first instance, the disability which is set down by the Medical Board as 65 per cent, or 70 per cent. It is found that men with 70 per cent, dis- ability who have been a'ccustomed to clerical or other light occupations have not much difficulty in supplementing their pensions. On the other hand, there are those who have been accustomed to manual labour requiring full health and strength, and they suffer considerable hardship. I hope during next week to present to honorable members some definite proposal to meet these latter cases.

The control of the Repatriation Department, mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition, is receiving the careful attention of the Government. It will have been noticed that the appointment of the Repatriation Commission has been renewed -for only one year, during which, it is hoped, the Government will be able to co-ordinate the Old-age and Invalid Pensions Department and the Pensions Branch of the Repatriation Department. The object is, at first, to enable these to run on parallel lines, with a view to their complete association. Both staffs are to be housed in the building of the Repatriation Department, and it is hoped ultimately to effect a considerable saving in the administrative charges. [10 August, 1923.]

The matter referred to by the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) is one of interpretation of the Act. The Repatriation Commission take "adequate means of support " to mean some amount of ready money sufficient to prevent absolute necessity. However, the manner in which this Act shall be interpreted and administered must be in accordance with the views and wishes of honorable members. In the short time still available, I should be glad to have an expression of opinion from honorable members on the point. My own idea is that a more liberal interpretation should be applied than in the past. The mothers of soldiers should at the very least be placed on the level of old-age and invalid pensioners in this regard. I am now referring to the amount of property and money that an old-age or invalid pensioner may possess without in any way jeopardizing the right to a pension. It is difficult- to say what should be the limit, and some discretionary power must be given to the Commission. At present an old-age pensioner may occupy his own house, or may possess £310 worth of property. This amount will be increased in the amending Bill to be introduced.

talk.start.para: . - We have now been sitting some twenty-five hours, during which we have, without discussion or explanation of any moment, voted £18,690,645. During the whole of this long night I have been endeavouring to catch the eye of the Chairman in order to air the grievances and desires of those whom I represent. I deprecate strongly the manner in which I have been deprived of. the opportunity to do so, even in the matter of postal and telephonic communication which so vitally interests every member of the community. Thus I have been unable to emphasize the importance of items which were included in last year's Estimates, but find no place in the Estimates before us. I refer particularly to the provision for a telephone exchange in the western suburbs of Adelaide. It is really shocking the way in which these Estimates are being bludgeoned through without any opportunity, as I say, for criticism or explanation. ' I observe that the vote for the Department pf Health has been decreased instead of increased. After the important speech on this subject by the honorable member for Darling (Mr. Blakeley) the other night, it is astounding to observe the apathy of the Government. I have had an opportunity to visit 'the serum depot, and I know how its operations are cramped by reason of the limited monetary support that it receives. The attention of the country should be directed to the anomalous and extraordinary methods of this Government in voting millions of money for indiscriminate immigration and reducing the amount to the important Department of Health. I hope that, when the time comes, the people, in their righteous indignation, will sweep the present Government from power, and return one prepared to restore and maintain responsible government.

. - I wish to revert to a case with which I dealt in :an earlier debate. This is not an isolated case, but one of many. 'The lady concerned has sent me the following letter which discloses all the facts : -

quote.para: I am the wife of- A.I.F. who embarked on the 11th April, 1916. I have two children, aged nine and ten years. My military allowance ceased on 18th October, 1917, my husband being reported as a deserter. I have not heard anything of my 'husband from that date. I applied to the Soldiers' Fund for assistance,' but was refused on the grounds that my husband was classed as a deserter. I was informed that the Fund was not for deserters' -wives. Miss- and Miss- accompanied me on that occasion. I was forced to apply -to the destitute authorities for assistance which was granted until Miss - advanced me the sum of £55 to start a small grocery business in which I failed, but I have since repaid the loan. When my business failed an official from the Military Department visited me .and inquired as to my circumstances, who stated " I believe Mrs.- that you are in a very bad position", and he informed me that I would be assisted from the Soldiers' Fund.

speech.para: She was .assisted from the South Australian Soldiers' Fund for a certain ' time, 1 and then the following letter was sent to her by the secretary of that fund : -

quote.para: Your verbal application for continued assistance from a fund has been placed before the committee, and I am now directed to say that in view of the fact that you have received continuous assistance for over two years and eight months, totalling a sum of £177, the committee feel the time has arrived when payment to you should cease: Your husband being classed by the military authorities as a deserter, places you upon a different footing to a soldier's widow, and, further, the committee understand that you are able to obtain ample remunerative employment.

speech.para: That woman worked for the secretary of the South Australian fund for a month during the illness of his wife, and because she refused to remain longer, owing to the ill-health of her sister-in-law, who was caring for her children, she was dismissed. She now works at the wash- tub to support herself and children. She lives with the widow of her brother, who paid the supreme sacrifice at the

Avar. She was not responsible for her husband's" desertion. Other cases such as this are neglected by the Government, and unless they are remedied we shall not be doing our duty to those who fought in the war. This woman told me that she was living on charity, because she could not obtain work. What do the Government intend to do, not only in this case, but in others? We are not seriously facing the legacy of the war. I enter my emphatic protest against the Government's neglect to accept full responsibility for the aftermath of war.

talk.start.para: . - I protest against the action of the Government in the vote for health purposes. A miserable sum of £15,000 has been provided for the treatment and control of venereal diseases throughout the Commonwealth'. This disease is a- grave and serious menace, as it vitally 'concerns the national health of Australia. Out of £121,000 set aside for health, £70,000 is devoted to the clerical staff, miscellaneous services, and so on. Fifty thousand pounds is < ear-marked for medical services, laboratory work, research, and investigation. That is quite insufficient for this vast continent. In the Estimates for this year the Health Department's, figures for Queensland and the Northern Territory are coupled together, but they are of sufficient importance to be kept separate. I cannot understand the reason for this, although it is perhaps necessary that, from an administrative stand-point,' Queensland should be in close touch with the Northern Territory. I have here . an Ordinance concerning the Northern Territory which was issued in March of last year. It deals with the question of venereal disease, and I commend it to honorable members for consideration. While it contains far-reaching provisions, such as the compulsory notification of venereal disease, and a penalty of £500 or imprisonment for five years for any person who marries knowing that he is suffering from venereal disease, yet to some extent we are left in the dark. We have not yet had .a statement from the Minister concerning the successful operation of that Ordinance. There is no amount on the Estimates for cancer research, and no mention of the Spahlinger treatment. If the population were menaced by an invading army, the Government would' act promptly. But they exhibit no haste to combat the ravages of fell diseases. It does not concern the Government, evidently, if through its failure to attend to national health, a high percentage of our manhood, in time of war, is certified to be medically unfit. A cure for tuberculosis would cast a ray of sunshine into the lives of thousands of our returned men. The Government are too busily concerned with the Imperial and Economic Conferences and the matter of Imperial defence to consider questions relating to the national health; but I trust that next session they will submit concrete proposals to this House. The Treasurer stated that certain things could not be done until an agreement was reached with the States. What has that to do with national health? It is no reason why the Government should shirk their responsibilities. I cannot understand why the Government, having at their disposal the advice of such medical men as the honorable members for Cowper and Calare, should submit this miserable proposal. I enter my protest against it.

. - Recently I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health why a supply of insulin had not been received by the Hobart Public Hospital. The Minister promised that supplies would be sent when available. The reply was not altogether satisfactory to the chairman of that hospital, and he wanted to know why supplies had been sent to country hospitals in Victoria in preference to large public hospitals, such as that at Hobart. I ask the Treasurer to investigate the matter.

. - A few moments ago the Treasurer (Dr. Earle Page) made the ridiculous statement that he wished, within the short period of fifteen minutes, to have the opinions of honorable members on matters concerning the allowance to be. granted to mothers of soldiers. For ten minutes of that time he has been out of the chamber. If the Treasurer intends to do business in that way he cannot expect to receive any opinions from this side of the Committee.

. - I appeal to the Treasurer, as a member of the medical profession having a knowledge of the scientific thought of the -present day, to recognise that the horrors of the recent war have so impressed themselves upon returned soldiers that nervous disorders may follow in the future. Adequate steps should be taken to meet that contingency.

speech.para: Proposed votes agreed to.

talk.start.para: . - I enter my protest that, because of the operation of the guillotine, I have been deprived of the opportunity to deal with a matter of great importance to the miners of Kalgoorlie.

speech.para: Motion (by Dr. Earle 'Page) agreed to-

quote.para: That the following resolution he reported -to the House: - " That, including the several sums already voted for such services, there be granted to His Majesty to . defray the charges for the year 1923-24, for the several services hereunder specified, a sum not exceeding £18,930,606.

speech.para: Resolution reported.
Motion (by Dr. Earle Page) put -
That the resolution reported from the Committee of Supply be adopted

talk.start.para: - Should I be out of order in asking your opinion, Mr. Speaker, on the conduct of the Government in rushing the Estimates through Parliament in a brutal manner?

talker.name: SPEAKER, Mr
Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon W A Watt

talk.start.para: - The honorable member would be out of order.

- During a division there is a certain amount of time at the disposal of honorable members which might be put to good use. Should I be in order in addressing a few words to the Postmaster-General on a matter on which I intended to address him during the discussion, but which I was prevented from doing "by the operation of the "guillotine " ? '

talker.name: SPEAKER, Mr
Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon W A Watt

talk.start.para: - The honorable member would not be in order in discussing the matter during a division.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Monday next, at 3 p.m.

talk.start.para: .- I move -

speech.para: That the word "Monday" bo left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the word "Sunday."
I submit this proposal with the object of facilitating the business of the Government and the departure of the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce) for England.

talk.start.para: - I second the amendment.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the. affirmative.

debate.para: Establishment of Laboratory or Health at Kalgoorlie - Proceedings in Committee of Supply.

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - Arrangements were made by the Commonwealth Government to establish a laboratory of health at Kalgoorlie, but the work has not been put in hand. The miners at Kalgoorlie are subject to the industrial disease known as miners' phthisis. Last year a sum of £500 was placed on the Estimates for the purpose of this laboratory, but only £10 was spent. An amount of £500 appears on the current year's Estimates, and I desire to know whether the expenditure will exceed £10, and . whether an effective laboratory can be established with an expenditure of £500. I find that £638 was provided on last year's Estimates for " Medical Officer (Laboratories)," and that there was no expenditure. This year £588 is being provided. Will any part of that sum be spent? The item " Technical Assistant (Laboratories), £209," was placed on last year's Estimates, and not a penny was spent. This year £210 is being provided. Will anything be spent? I trust that this work will be proceeded with. Dr. Cumpston, Director of Health, when in Kalgoorlie, pointed out that one man in every three, working at the face in the big mines, was suffering from miner's phthisis. I trust that the Government will treat this as an urgent matter.

.- I desire to bring before you, sir, a matter of some importance. Discussion on the Estimates had to close at 12 o'clock to-day. At one minute to twelve three honorable members rose to speak. Had each of those honorable members been called upon in turn each would have had 20 seconds to develop his theme. They naturally hoped that the Standing Orders would be complied with, and that this meagre measure of. time would bo allowed them.I regret to say that, while these three honorable members were endeavouring to catch the eye of the Tern-, porary Chairman of Committees (Mr. Bayley), that gentleman rose in anticipation, before the expiration of the time fixed, and stated the question. I desire merely to add, as the King's hangman said when he pulled the lever, " we will let the subject drop."

talker.name: WATT, William
Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon, W A Watt

talk.start.para: - For the information of the honorable member for Batman (Mr. Brennan), if he seriously desires me to give him the information, "I may say that the House takes no official cognisance of what occurs in Committee, unless it is officially reported.

talker.role: Prime Minister and Minister for External Affairs
talker.name: BRUCE, Stanley
Mr BRUCE

talk.start.para: . - In view of the statements made by the honorable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. A. Green) I can assure him that the question of establishing a laboratory of health at Kalgoorlie will receive the fullest consideration of the Government.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 12.17 p.m. (Saturday).
